turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: No, Mother, he's lying...

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Shut up, Doll. I'll cut your guts

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Chattanooga. I had St. Louis, Missouri.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Buddy, I'm worried about Rose.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: She hasn't got any sense. In some ways, she's awful dumb.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: It isn't that she hasn't got any sense, Doll. Her basic intelligence is probably above average, maybe quite a bit above average.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Then why does she act so dumb?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Dumbness doesn't concern her, Doll. And neither does smartness. You see --

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: What is Rose going to do? Where can she go?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: They've been in there the longest kind of time. I can't stand it, I gotta find out what's going on.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: You better not snoop, Daddy'll kill you!

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Mother is struggling desperately. In fact she's fighting like a tiger. But I don't know, it's close, it's mighty close.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Buddy... does Rose really... "do it" with all those boys and men?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Doll, don't ask childish questions.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Well, if she's got any sense at all, she'll listen to that.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Sense doesn't mean anything to Rose. But I think we're on safe ground now. Daddy chained up the ladder, whoever it is can't get in the house.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: What's goin' on?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Rose says she's goin' to have a baby and she sure looks it, but I don't think so.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: A baby... and she isn't even married.

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: That's the least of her troubles. Rose had a rare tropic disease and the little tubes in her that babies swim down are all stopped up, she told me all about it.

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: If it isn't a baby... what is it?

turns.speaker: DOLL
turns.text: Why is it taking so long?

turns.speaker: BUDDY
turns.text: Here comes Daddy.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, you rascal, where'd you come from?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Hello, Daddy. How are you?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: About as good as can be expected with one foot in the grave. Good to see you, son.  Did you bring any of that Yankee whisky with you?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: It isn't Yankee whisky, Daddy, it's Scotch.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: It's Yankee whisky to me.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: I can use a drink after the plane ride I had.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Your wife and children are back in New Hampshire in the snow?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Yeah, they're in the snow.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Are they polar bears, too?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Good God, the way you live here. This place hasn't been dusted since Mother died. Look at that goddamned refrigerator.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Got another twenty years in it, boy.  By the way, son, do you recall Rose, that pretty blonde girl who came to our house way back in 1935 or 1936 and caused such a damnable commotion.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Of course I recall Rose. In fact I've been thinking of no one else for the last hour and a half.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: How could that be, son?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Dave Wilkie of all people was sitting by me on the plane -- her first husband. It's funny you would mention Rose. Did you hear from her?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: What's all this about Rose? What do you mean, you heard from her in a manner of speaking?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Oh, I heard from her, I got a letter from her, she's fine. But there is some sad news.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: What sad news? Did her cancer come back?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Oh, no, no, she got all over that. Rose is fine. Let's sit down, son.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Is her husband sick or something?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, it's another thing. I was going to write you about it, but since you were coming down anyway I thought I'd wait till you got here. What did Dave Wilkie have to say?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: The pitiful son of a bitch said Rose was a nymphomaniac.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Um-hmm, and I suppose that incensed you?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: You're damn right it incensed me, the miserable bastard. He also said the kikes and the niggers have taken over Washington. D.C.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yeah, I know, he was up here. It's pitiful like you say. When he lost Rose it ruined the man, it destroyed him totally when he lost Rose.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: He didn't lose her, he threw her away.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yes, I guess he did. He threw her away and it was the mistake of his life.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: You know, I don't know this town any more. All this traffic, new buildings, prosperity...  Where have the years gone, Daddy? Where is the little town I knew as a boy?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: At rest in the creative universe with Mother, son.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: That's what she would say herself.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: A wonderful woman, boy.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: It always gives me a funny feeling to come home. Dear old Southland. Gone. It's all gone, Daddy --  -- except you, you're still here.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Not for long, boy. I've outstayed my welcome already.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: It's funny you would mention Rose, I was thinking about her all the way up in the car.  Or maybe it isn't so funny.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I'm older than hell, boy. But this Yankee whisky is mighty fine, I'll say that.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: All right, Daddy. We have our drink, we're out on the patio, you have prepared me for it. Rose's cancer has come back, hasn't it?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, son, she is dead.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Dead, Rose is dead? You mean... she died?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I am afraid so, son. About a week ago. Her husband phoned me, she had asked him to call me if anything happened.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: But... but how? She was young! Rose wasn't old!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: She was fifty-six, son. Of course she didn't look it, nowhere near it. The cancer came back, I'm afraid I fibbed about that. But it was very quick, son. She was in the hospital only two weeks, and the last week she didn't know anything.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Excuse me, I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Well, you have knocked me for a hell of a loop, old man. A hell of a loop.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I know. You loved her. So did I. It was an awful shock to me, too. An awful shock. Rose was so alive it's hard to believe.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: I can't believe it, Daddy. I know it must be true, but I can't believe it.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: It's true, son. The girl with the cornflower eyes is dead, she is no more,

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Why Rose? Why Rose, Daddy?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Nobody lives forever, boy. Who'd want to?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: That's a hell of a thing to say. Why, Rose?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Now look, boy, get a grip on yourself. Rose had a good life. She found her. Right, didn't she? She triumphed over everything, what are you blubbering about?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: I'm not blubbering.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: The point is you don't grow up like that on a diet of sorghum and hominy grits. She got protein somewhere, she's a very strong girl and I think she'll live... despite the delay in medical treatment.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That's all I want to know.  Lets get out of here before I get the epizootics myself. Thank you, Doctor, for your discourse, it was fascinating, no doubt.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, it's a disaster. I don't know what to say, Doctor, I am floored. How dangerous is the operation?

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Any major operation is dangerous. However, as we know from her previous illness, she's a very strong girl.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, if it isn't malignant and she can get through the operation all right, it might be better than her really being pregnant. She doesn't even know who the father might have been.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Oh, it's definitely better, beyond question. A fatherless child, an ignorant girl with no job, no money, no home. It's fortunate, a blessing really, and a stroke of good luck for another reason I want to mention to you.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Go ahead, Doctor, I think I am following you.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: First, about the girl's history. Evidently she's been very promiscuous since early childhood, she has no control over her sexual impulses. Furthermore, she is permanently barren, she can't have children.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Go on, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I am ahead of you.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: Then... may I speak quite frankly with you, Mr. Hillyer?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Please do.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I have of course observed the girl in treating her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: DR. MARTINSON
turns.text: I think we both know her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yes, we know her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It isn't the fourth dimension. To you it's the fourth dimension, maybe, to me it's simply the truth.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, well, well. So Miss Rosebud has arrived. Un-hmm. And you're all assembled here. Yes, indeed. Un hmmm.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Good morning, sweetheart. Beautiful day.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, it's so nice I thought I'd work outside.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: How goes it, darlin'?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Slow, hon. But at least I can concentrate now that Rose is here.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What do you think of her, honey?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Turn up your hearing aid.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Your hearing aid, it's buzzing at me like a snake.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh. Did you say something?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I asked you what you think of Rosebud, now that she's been here a while.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Honey, she's perfect. She works all the time and she's wonderful with the children. And they love her, even Brother likes her though he won't admit it. I think she's just perfect.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Um-hmm. Almost too perfect.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: And she's such a good-hearted thing, there isn't an ounce of harm or malice in her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I'll admit I don't see any flies on her yet.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: There are no flies on Rose, I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, she must have done something to encourage those scoundrels in Birmingham, even if she did run away from them.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, let's hope for the best, darlin'.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Hope for the best? I don't understand all this skepticism. I thought you liked Rose.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I love Rosebud, I am wild about Rosebud. I just hope she doesn't turn out to be a hidden hotcha character, that's all. We have growing children in the house.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Hotcha character. If I had to live with your cynicism, I wouldn't want to live at all. What you can't understand is that the creative forces of the universe are positive, not negative.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, darlin', don't go off into the fourth dimension.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'm not in the fourth dimension --  -- you are in the fourth dimension, when you allow skepticism and doubt to take control. As Blake said, if God had doubt the sun would go out.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Forgive my crudity, darlin'. I don't understand these deeper things the way you do.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Be nice to Rose. She's never had a real home.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You're a wonderful woman, darlin'. As long as you're around, I'm sure the sun wouldn't dare go out.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I'll drive you, darlin'. You've got no business behind the wheel of an automobile. You don't think about what you're doing and you'll run into a telephone pole.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I think about what I'm doing all the time, and I've got as much business behind the wheel of an automobile as anybody. Besides, I want you to stay and help Rose with the dishes, the poor girl isn't feeling well.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, darlin'.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What's the matter, hon? Is anything wrong?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, darlin'. Just that damnable insomnia in reverse. I sleep like a baby for an hour then I'm wide awake. You go back to sleep.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Um-hmm. Well, that is the damndest outfit I ever saw in my life. You walk down the street like that and they'll put you in jail, Rose.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Why, they won't either. She looks pretty. And I wish you wouldn't pick on the poor girl all the time. Don't listen to him, Rose, you look pretty, even beautiful.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Lay off of that stuff, son. It upsets your mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'm serious. We forget he's just a child. I wish you'd speak to him.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I'll take him with me downtown.  And you, too, Rose, if you want a ride.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: They'll put her in jail. The damn little fool might as well be naked.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, it is a little tight. But it isn't as bad as all that. No one will notice unless they have such thoughts in the first place.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Who doesn't have such thoughts?  We'd better get going.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You're not having lunch?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Just half-a-cup of coffee. I never eat, darlin', you know that. Not eating and reverse insomnia are my curses. Let's go, Rose, you and Brother, let's hit the road.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose, you and Brother wait in the car. I want to speak for a moment Lo Mr. Hillyer.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I wish you wouldn't pick on Rose and tease her like that. Of course her clothes are silly, but she's ignorant, naive, she doesn't know any better.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: The girl worries me. If she walks down the street like that, an army will be following her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, I admit that outfit isn't very modest. But she doesn't mean any harm, she just wants to attract, attention.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: She will succeed.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't think you understand her. It isn't sex she wants, it's love she wants and this is the only way she knows how to get it.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That farmer in Gadsden was awful eager to get rid of her, and I'm beginning to see why.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: He and his wife both said she had a fine moral character and was wonderful with children.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, she loves children, all right.  She loves everybody.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But that's a wonderful quality, not a bad quality.  Have a little patience with her. She's such a good-hearted little thing and tries so hard.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You are the one who's good-hearted.  As for Rose, let's hope for the best.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Be kind to her. She loves you so much.  In a perfectly proper way, of course.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, she's back.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Quarter of twelve.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Is she all right?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't see any bruises or broken bones.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Why shouldn't she go out and have boyfriends?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No reason at all, darlin'.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, I wish you'd stop criticizing and picking on her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Forgive my crudity, darlin'. All I'm saying is that a girl who would wear clothes like that is going to get in trouble sooner or later.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, time will tell, won't it?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yes, darlin', time will tell.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: That sulky boy was here again this afternoon. I was almost scared, he wouldn't go away.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose, my patience is wearing thin. First a scruffy man who runs like a deer and now a sulky boy who wont go away. This is getting to be a regular monkey and dog show.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, it isn't Rose's fault boys and men like her. You cant blame her for that, hon.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose, I realize you don't know this boy, but if you know anybody who does know him, if you have even a faint clue as to who he might be, then convey to him that he had better stay away from my house and stop scaring my wife... and I don't mean maybe.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Oh, shut up, Rose. Shut your mouth and quit crying!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I will not sit here and listen to you be brutal to this poor girl.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I am not being brutal to her!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You certainly are! She has an awful toothache, look at her jaw, it's all swollen.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Darlin', it is not my fault if the girl has epizootics --

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: -- I am not responsible for her epizootics and I did not bring about her epizootics. Now listen to me. When I have to get up in the middle of the night and defend my home with a shotgun against a couple of damned scoundrels fistfighting in the bushes --

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Scoundrels? They weren't scoundrels, they were just boys.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Boys? You say to me boys?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes! Yes, I say that to you, they were boys! Boy friends of Rose, chat's what they were, and why shouldn't she have boy friends? Do you want her to be unnatural? Don't you think she's human the same way you are yourself? It's the South, that's what it is, the South with its horrible traditions, of slavery and crime and the oppression of women, who are just as good as men and just as human!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Now darlin', what has the South got to do with this?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: And when I try to talk to you seriously, when I try to explain to you the unlimited creative power of life, how beautiful it would be if we gave up this hopeless struggle and simply loved each other from our hearts, what do you do -- you mock me!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't intend to mock you, dear. I respect your philosophy. It's beyond my comprehension, but I respect it.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Now you listen to me, Rose --

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Just a moment! You are not going to fire this girl for an innocent thing like having boy friends, not while there is breath in my body!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't intend to fire her, darlin'.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It isn't her fault if she's popular... what?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I said I don't intend to fire her. I just want to ask her to keep her boy friends away from my home and hearth, that's all.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, that's very reasonable. Howe I hate to bring it up, but she's got an awful toothache, we've got to carry her to the dentist.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I'm sorry, darlin', I hate it as much as you do.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, she does seem to cause a lot of trouble, I admit. But she doesn't mean any harm and it'll break the children's hearts, they all love her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: It's because of the children she's got to go. I don't want to be holier-than-thou, but the girl doesn't have the same outlook we do. Morals don't mean a thing to her, not a thing, and we can't have a girl like that in this house.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Who is to say our morals are better than hers?  But maybe you're right. She could... influence Dolly...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That is exactly what I'm afraid of.  The girl has got to go, darlin'.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But morals come from the heart, not from rigid rules and empty laws. And in her heart Rose has never hurt anyone and she never would. Therefore, she's not immoral. Not really.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Now look, darlin', this is no time to go off into the fourth dimension.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But what I said is the simple truth. And now I see something else, I see more deeply into it...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: How could Rose really be a bad influence on Dolly? She has a loving nature, you ought to want someone like that around your children. Why do you think those boys and men like her?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I have a pretty good idea.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: If you mean sex, you couldn't be more wrong. Rose likes those boys and men, she has love in her heart, and that is what they want. It's the most rare and beautiful thing in life and that is why they follow her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: They follow her because she's a --  -- no, I won't say that.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What she doesn't understand is that her behavior is disturbing to other people. She's young, she's got to learn to restrain the life force that's in her. Its creative, but in her case it's too creative.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Darlin', Rose has got to go!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'll talk to her, I'll reason with her.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Excuse me, sir, are you calling my wife a liar?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Honey, please...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I can't stand that polecat. They ought to hang him.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You don't like him because he's a Yankee. He's a brilliant doctor.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: He's a polecat, dear.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rosebud looked pretty pitiful in that bed.  I hope she'll be all right, but I still think we ought to fire her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't see how you can even think of it now.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Honey, Dr. Martinson isn't a rascal, he's one of the finest physicians in Glenville. He studied at Johns Hopkins University.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't care where the polecat studied.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Sometimes the negativism and cynicism in you makes me want to vomit.  Your real trouble is that you're anti-intellectual. The irony is women are supposed to be emotional, but I never saw anybody who depended more on emotion and prejudice than you do.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She's like a different person. Being so sick made a big impression on her. I really think she's learned a lesson.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Um-hmm.  Come with me, Brother. I want to show you something.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She hasn't actually done anything...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Just a moment, dear.  We can't have it, Rose. Can you behave yourself -- or not? That is the question, to behave or not to behave, to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous chastity and keep your skirt down or to hoist it in the light of the moon and make whoopee -- that is the coil shuffling question.  If you can't behave I am going to fire you and I say it in front of you and Mrs. Hillyer and I mean it. I point my rigid finger right at your nose, Rose, and I stare unwaveringly into your big blue eyes and I tell you... this is a final warning. Do you hear me?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: It has been three weeks since I "fired" her. Is there no way to get rid of this girl? Are we stuck with her for life?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She can't get a job, it's a depression. And we can't just throw her out on the street.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: The hell we can't.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She does look a little peaky.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, she doesn't, she's fine, fine. She's perfectly healthy, don't give her ideas.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Her plan is obvious, plain as day. She's going on a hunger strike. The question is, how do we foil her?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: She's just nervous and worried. And you would be, too, if you had no job and no place to go.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Something has got to be done or Rose is going to be in this house forever.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think --

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It sounds like a farm to me. Calling it a dairy establishment, that's just trickery and flummery.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Trickery and flummery or not, she's going there tomorrow on the bus! It's settled! And I must say we've been more than fair to you, Rose, it's pretty selfish and mean hearted of you to sit there and cry like that!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: This is a total catastrastroke. As of this moment I am stumped, I admit, I am stumped and treed both, the hound dogs have me surrounded.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Poor thing, don't cry, Rose. I know you feel awful, but don't cry, honey, nobody's perfect. Who's the father, dear?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You're not going to get anywhere with that line of questioning. The problem is, what are we going to do?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: That's why I'm asking her who the father is. It's the most vital question of all. Who's the father, dear?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: She already told you, she doesn't know.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But she must know... unless... unless... Rose, was there more than one person?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Ah, ha! Hold the phone! No forwarding address, huh?  In the shock of this brilliant move, I forgot something.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What did you forget?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I forgot that Rose will lie like a child. She's no more pregnant than I am, she just doesn't want to go to that farm!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Honey!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: She doesn't have to take her panties off, we can see her stomach with 'em on. All she has to do is pull up her dress and let us see her belly.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'd say about three months. Are you satisfied?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I am poleaxed and in a non compos mentis condition. I wash my hands or the whole thing.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: This conversation is making me a little sick.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Honey, that's no way to talk to the Doctor, he's merely doing his job, dear.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Reluctantly, I do. It would be a blessing to her and everyone else. The girl is oversexed and I say -- spay her!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Over... my... dead... body!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I thought I knew you. I thought I knew you better, I thought in your heart you were a good and kind man. Well, I can't believe what I've just heard in this room. A defenseless girl depending on you for protection, and you propose to mutilate and destroy her. How could you listen even for a moment to that sadistic man?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, now, darlin'... give me a chance to defend myself.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I can't believe you really meant it, if I did I'd want to die. You aren't a male monster, that man is but you aren't. Look me in the eye and tell me, do you really want to take Rose's womanhood away from her when it's all she has got?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I... I hadn't thought about it that much. I was thinking... well, it's an idea, the girl is oversexed, and...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Rose isn't oversexed, that's ridiculous. If you're going to talk nonsense, I don't want to talk to you at all. Rose is exactly the same as the rest of us, except more so.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I know, more so. That's why I was thinking... maybe she'd be better off.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Better off? How could she ever find love and happiness, if you did what you're talking about? Are you insane?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: How is she?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: It's twenty after one.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I don't understand it. Even in the wild days she was never as late as this.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I'm afraid it's my fault. I made her feel guilty this morning --  Brother, what are you doing up?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Why, that looks like Dave Wilkie,

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You know Dave, his wife used to do dressmaking for you before she died.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, thank God we are rid of her at last. And the best thing of all is that she's happy. The little nut is happy, she found Mr. Right in the nick of time!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, yes, she's happy. Of course Dave doesn't have her life force, not at all. There isn't much furniture in his house, just a table and one or two chairs, whereas Rose has furniture coming out of the windows.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Honey, he is Mr. Right.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes, I think so. He adores her, it's almost pitiful the way he worships her. I just hope she isn't too much for him.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right. Now as head of this household I have a couple of remarks to make. It is my dear wife's belief, which I accept although I do not totally grasp it, that to hire a person to do household work is a criminal practice. Therefore, you are here not as a servant, you are here as a friend, as a guest and hopefully as a member of this family. You will eat your meals with us, you will share life itself with us -- in love and harmony, dear Rosebud, in love and harmony. Do you understand me?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rosebaby Blossom, these are the most delicious candied yams I ever ate! Why, they just melt in my mouth. And this fried chicken is fit for a king. How do you do it, Peachbird? What is the secret of your art, Plum Blossom, huh?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know, I... I...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rosebird Baby, you are the light of my life, darlin'. How did we ever get by without you?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I... I'll get the grits.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Ahh-hem! Now, Rose, get off my lap. What are you doing, girl? Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, crazy about you! Kiss me, Mr. Hillyer!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Why, I'm not going to kiss you, you crazy girl. Now I'm telling you again, get off my lap. Come on, Rose, get up. Now you get up, I say, and stop this!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No, no! You don't understand, I love you! It's real love and I can't help it! Please kiss me, Mr. Hillyer, I love you, I love you so much...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, all right. Now calm down, Rose, the children will hear you. Calm down, let's talk... about this thing, let's discuss it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Don't make me... me... me... get up!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Calm down, Rose, let's calm down and discuss it ...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Goddamn you, girl! You've made me make a fool out of myself, damn your hide, but let me tell you I am standing at the pass of Thermopylae and I won't budge! The very idea, my own home with children in the house, to say nothing of my wife -- oh-h, you had better believe I am standing at Thermopylae, you little nut, you had better believe it! What are you, crazy? A man is supposed to be a fool like this, but a woman is supposed to have some control and sense! Are you a nitwit? What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh-h, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, Mr. Hillyer... I just... couldn't help myself. I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose, Rose, Rose, you poor miserable little child, don't you know I love you? Do I have to put my hand on your body or kiss your pretty lips to prove it? You are beautiful to me, Rose, I've loved you since you first came here, darlin'. And don't you know Mrs. Hillyer loves you, too, that she's already taken you into her heart, and that that woman's heart is as wide as the blue sky itself and as deep as the stars?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, I know. She's so sweet, she's been so good to me...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Do you know what a friend you have got there? Do you know she would fight for you like a tiger, that she would fly to your defense in an instant with all the courage in her soul if anyone tried to hurt you? Is this any way to repay her trust and love? Are you ashamed as I am ashamed?  Don't cry, honey, don't cry. But let me warn you, damn your hide, this is Thermopylae and I am standing here. Do you hear me, damn you. I am standing at Thermopylae and the Persians shall not pass! Now get your tail out of here and go wash those dishes, and stop crying!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose, what are you doing up?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Nothin', just goin' to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Is anything wrong?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, good night.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Nothin'. I got myself up, that's all.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Got yourself up?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yeah. I'm goin' out.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You're so sweet.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: If you've got time before you go "out," get me a half-a-cup of coffee, Rose. Not a whole cup, a half-a-cup.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Why, sure, always got time to get you a half-a-cup, and one of these days I'm gonna get you a whole cup and see what happens.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Um-hmmuhh. I never drink a whole cup, my nerves can't stand the caffeine. Ehh-hh, Lord awful insomnia in reverse last night. Lay there and sweated blood for hours.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That's a pretty stylish skirt, Rose. The only thing I don't understand is how did you ever get it on.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, it has buttons.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: How can the buttons stand the pressure?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: There are more on the other side.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What have you got in your hair, girl?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: My rose. It's kind of like a motto. People will say, there comes Rose with her rose.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You were up late last night, too, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir. I had to go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Where do you want me to let you out, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, anywhere downtown.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You don't know where you're going?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, I'll just mosey around here and there.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Is this ill right?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: It'll do just fine.  Bye-bye, see you later.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, Rose, my sleep was a little disturbed last night, and so was Mrs. Hillyer's, and so was the children's. How about you? Was your sleep disturbed, too?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Hillyer, it was. I... I heard strange voices in the night.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Strange voices, Rose?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Now Rose, stop behaving as if you're Bo Peep. Those men had a flight last night because of some female in this house, and it wasn't Dolly or Mrs. Hillyer.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Ohhh-hh, ohhh...

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Oh, shut up, Rose, eat your cornflakes!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Darlin', I'll take a taxi to the hotel. You and Brother can handle the girl's epizootics. I'll just say one more thing.  Rose, I told you you had a friend in Mrs. Hillyer, didn't I, that she would fight for you like a tiger?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, thanks to her, and thanks to this case of epizootics, you are getting another chance.  But don't try my patience again. We have growing children in this house. Do you understand me?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Good morning, Rose. And how do you feel today?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Wonderful. Except I can touch the place back there with my tongue, I wouldn't even know I had that tooth pulled.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I know it, I just got the bill for it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Boy, for four or five days there I didn't think I'd live. But I'm my old self again!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Umm. Well. Yes. But no more strange voices in the night, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, no, sir.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I got an awful bad cold.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: That's all you've got to say, you've got a bad cold?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, I don't know what happened. They were arguin' about baseball, then all of 'em started fightin'. As for that policeman, I didn't bite him, I don't think I bit him.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I didn't mean to bite him. He was hitting Horton with a blackjack in the meanest way and... and I bit him accidental.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I have to go back to the hotel. I'm on duty at the desk and who knows a quest might arrive. I will see you at suppertime, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I didn't mean to bite him, I really didn't.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I will see you at suppertime, Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, air.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I mean a human investment, Rose, we care about you, you matter to us. But we have innocent and unformed children in this house and the monkey and dog show has got to stop. Do you hear me?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: There ain't nobody here, Mr. Hillyer! Honest, there ain't!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Where is he? Where have you got him hid?  Ah, ha!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: And who, Rose, may I ask, is that?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, it's Billy.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: And what, may I ask, was Billy doing here?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, Mr. Hillyer, Billy's very poor, he don't have no money and there wasn't no place else to go.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, it was a silly question.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: He's a nice boy, you'd like him. He wants to be a fireman.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Ye gods and little fishes, a fireman. Put on some clothes, Rose, you're naked as a jay bird. When you're dressed, come on downstairs. I'm afraid your friend Billy is injured, where are his clothes?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Under the mattress. I hid 'em so you wouldn't be mad. He wants to marry me, he loves me. I can't marry him, he's too young and hasn't got no job, but he loves me... now you wouldn't hurt him, would you?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Mr. Hillyer, I know it was bad and I hadn't ought to of done it. But I'm only a human girl and I... I ain't always perfect. I promise I won't let him in the house no more, I promise. Won't you and Mrs. Hillyer forgive me?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose, darlin', you break my heart. But I am only a human man myself of the father variety. Rose, pack your bag, baby, as of this moment you are hired, mired and fired.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, Rose, going out to look for a job today?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What's the use, there ain't none.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Mmm. Would you get me another half a-cup of coffee, dear?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: God forbid. You're not sick, Rose, forget it. Don't get any notions in your head, you're not sick.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, I have got news! I called long distance and spoke to Cousin Hop and you'll be glad to know, Rose, I have found you a job!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Tennessee?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Yes, Tennessee, a lovely state!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well. What kinda job is it?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Ahh-hh, you'll like it. It's a fine, outdoor-type job.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You mean a farm?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, no, not exactly. It isn't a farm in the sense that it's a farm. Not at all. It's a... dairy establishment. You'll 1ike it! I'm sure you'll like it because it's so... peaceful!

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I'm not cryin' because of me, I'm cryin' because of somebody else.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: What baby? What baby? What baby are you speaking about?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Mine.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Your baby?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, mine. I'm going to have one.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Good God almighty. This is a catastrophe, they won't hire her.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: No, you're not.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Hillyer, I am.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, tell us, Rose, what makes you think you're pregnant?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I haven't had my period for three months and my stomach is getting big.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: It's so, Mr. Hillyer.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: All right, damn it. We've seen you with your clothes off around here, stand up and pull up your dress and let's take a look!

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: You're looking very chipper this morning, Rose. Sow do you feel?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Perfect, wonderful, good as I ever felt! Except for a big old scar on my stummick, I wouldn't even know I been in the hospital.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Well, we know you were there. The bill that hospital sent was absolutely horrendous.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well, I'll pay you that back sometime, Mr. Hillyer.

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Rose... I hate to be mean, but...  Oh, nevermind, forget it.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: What was it, Mr. Hillyer?

turns.speaker: DADDY
turns.text: Nothing, Rose.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Excuse me... your voice is familiar and I'm sure I know you from somewhere...

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Awww-rr, Buddy, come on, you know me!

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Well, I... I... ah-h, let's see...

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: It's Dave Wilkie! I'm Dave Wilkie, don't you remember me?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Oh. Oh, God. Of course, Dave, how are you?

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Well, I am in the construction business, Buddy, and without braggin' I have done real good at it.  There are those who wouldn't have expected that out of me.  Right now I'm buildin' a giant motel unit near Alexandria, outside Washington, D.C. Not fi-nance, I'm on the construction side.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Well, that's interesting, Dave. I always liked Washington, it's a pretty town.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Oh, it's all right, beats Jew York. But the niggers have took it over, just like every other city we got, only worse.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Ha ha, course you make a lot more.  What's that you got there, Buddy?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Galley proof.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Galley what?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Page proof of a book I'm working on.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: How about that. Well, you always were a screwball.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: I don't mean that the way it sounds.  Imagine it, a book. And I used to know you personal way back when.  Tell me something, Buddy, how do you dream up all that stuff?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Well, actually, we have a little black boy named Her---t who lives in the garage. He does it for me.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Heh heh heh heh, same old Buddy, always jokin' around. Almost as much of a joker as your Daddy.  I saw your Daddy a coupla years ago, I was up in Glenville lookin' at a motel site. I guess that's where you're headed, huh, to see him?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: That's right, Dave, I'm headed for Glenville on a whisperin' jet.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Hey, girl! Hey, you, give us another drink!  Dumb little bitch, supposed to give us two in the first place.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Took your time gettin' here.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: She has other things to do, Dave.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Tell me about that job in Alexandria, Dave, the big motel you're building.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Near Alexandria. It isn't in Alexandria, it is outside it.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: I see. Outside it.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: That's correct -- outside it, not in it. As for the job, well, the Jewboy suppliers give me a lot of grief and we use a pile of niggers to haul and tote and they ain't worth a sorry-ass damn.  But I can build anything, Buddy. Give me the plans and I can build a goddamn staircase to the moon. It's a fact, I can build anything...  ... but she never believed that. Oh, hell, no, she never believed in me.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Um-m, well...

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Doubted my ability all along, the little bitch. I never remarried, Buddy, you know that, don't you?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Well, no, I didn't actually.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: She's te reason -- cured me of women once and for all. Oh, I got rid of her, Buddy, I didn't waste no time kickin' that bitch out. Hell, she was screwin' everybody in Savannah. I caught her in a motel with this long tall son of a bitch and boy did I beat the everlastin' piss out of him!

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: She didn't marry him, though, later she married another guy and went to Winston-Salem. It didn't last That girl couldn't have no lastin' marriage, she left him and married another dumb sucker and went out west. Little bitch left him, too, and you know what she's married to right now?  A kike. That's right, some kind of kike horse doctor named Schapiro out in Seattle, who's got the nerve to have the same first name I got. Wouldn't you know it, Rose would wind up married to a goddamn kike? She was always out of her friggin' head and I'll tell you why.  Buddy, she was sick in her mind and between her legs, too. She was a nymphomaniac.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Dave, you are as full of shit as a Christmas turkey and you know it. Now if you want to start a fight on this plane and get yourself in jail, go right ahead. But I am telling you, you are full of shit right up to your eyeballs.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: I don't want to start no fight with you, Buddy. Why do you say I'm full of shit?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Dave Schapiro is no horse doctor and Rose has been a good wife to him for a long time. To call her a nymphomaniac is the most stupid thing I ever heard in my life.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: You loved her, didn't you. Well, so did I.  You'll have to admit she had four husbands.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Yeah, it took her a while to grow up and find Mr. Right, but she did it. She found him.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: She used to call me Mr. Right. Remember that, Buddy?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Yeah, I remember it.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Well, got to get a plane to Savannah. Great running into you, Buddy. Give my best to your Daddy.

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Yeah, I'll do that, Dave.

turns.speaker: DAVE WILKIE
turns.text: Ah-h, if you happen to run into Rose sometime... do me a favor, give her a message for me, will you?

turns.speaker: WILLCOX HILLYER
turns.text: Dave, I haven't seen Rose for years.
